caption: Museum with an extensive collection of military history. Napoleon I tomb can be seen in the old church. The museum and Napoleon tomb is included in same price.  The medical arms are great to see, WW1 and WW2 also good but lots of text only in French so not so good.

One of my favorite landmarks in Paris. You can learn a lot about their military history and most of all, you can see the Napoleon‚Äôs grave! Its massive and it should be massive so it matches the man laying in it! The chapel is great also and the energy inside it is fantastic! Must visit for history lovers.

For anyone with an interest in French Military history, this has to be visited at least once. The contents of the museum are priceless and the architucture some of the best of its kind in the world. The exterior is splendid and has a view from the Seine worth a photo.
A worth visiting! A stunning museum. A great French military history and you can see Napoleon‚Äôs tomb! Over all one of the best museum I ever visited!

A Must-Visit in Paris  H√¥tel des Invalides is an amazing place to explore if you‚Äôre in Paris. The golden dome is absolutely stunning and catches your eye from far away. Inside, seeing Napoleon‚Äôs tomb was incredible‚Äîit‚Äôs so grand and impressive.  The museum here is really interesting too, with loads of exhibits about French military history, from ancient armor to modern times. Even if you‚Äôre not a big history fan, there‚Äôs so much to see, and it‚Äôs all presented really well.  The whole place has a peaceful vibe, with lovely courtyards and gardens that are perfect for a quiet stroll. It‚Äôs a great mix of history, architecture, and a little bit of nature. Definitely worth a visit!

‚ÄúStunning architectural masterpiece with a golden dome that shines over Paris. The D√¥me des Invalides is rich in history, housing Napoleon‚Äôs grand tomb and a fascinating military museum. A must-visit for history and architecture enthusiasts!‚Äù

Les Invalides is a truly unmissable landmark in Paris. Its gorgeous golden dome dominates the Parisian skyline and the incredible Baroque building is magnificent as well.  Inside, the museums are interesting and the interior is beautiful too, especially under the dome near Napoleon‚Äôs tomb.

It's a large complex of buildings containing Museum of Army( Mus√©e de I‚ÄôArmee), Museum of Liberation, the Dome and Cathedral where lies Napoleon. The whole place was built in 17 century by Louis XIV for the elderly, disable and homeless soldiers in his army. The  complex was magnificent especially knowing its history. It‚Äôs the only one serving this type of purpose in the world at the time. There are cannons displayed in the courtyard. Going into the complex is free. Only need to go through a security check. If want to see the museums, a ticket is required at the entrance. We used the museum pass to see the Museum of Army which was very impressive. I took one star off was because of the unclear instruction of the entrance. We were at the gate directly outside the Dome but the gate was closed. Without any notice or signage directing visitors to the correct entrance, we walked a large circle to its back to its side then finally found the entrance on the other side. When we finished visit and tried to go out, we were told the gate in front of the Dome would only open after 2pm. They could do a better job to give a clear instruction of where the entrance is located. Better yet, to open the gate on the main street in front of the Dome.

Les Invalides is an impressive historical site with stunning architecture, and the tomb of Napoleon is an absolute highlight. The grandeur of his resting place reflects the significance of his legacy in French history. Walking through the museum, you can feel the weight of history all around you. The exhibits are well-curated and provide great insights into France's military past. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Paris!

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è 5/5  The H√¥tel des Invalides in Paris is a must-visit for anyone who appreciates history, architecture, and French heritage. Originally commissioned by Louis XIV in 1671 as a hospital and retirement home for war veterans, the site has since evolved into a complex that houses museums, monuments, and the final resting place of Napoleon Bonaparte. My visit to this iconic landmark was truly unforgettable.  From the moment you arrive, you‚Äôre struck by the grandeur of the architecture. The vast courtyard, known as the Cour d‚ÄôHonneur, is lined with symmetrical arcades and cannons, setting the tone for the military significance of the site. The highlight of the complex is undoubtedly the D√¥me des Invalides, with its dazzling gold leaf dome that dominates the skyline. Standing beneath this dome and admiring its intricate frescoes and gilded details is breathtaking.  One of the most profound experiences here is visiting Napoleon‚Äôs tomb, housed beneath the dome. The tomb is made of red quartzite and rests on a green granite base, surrounded by twelve statues representing his military victories. The space is awe-inspiring and solemn, with intricate mosaics and inscriptions that pay tribute to Napoleon‚Äôs legacy. Whether or not you‚Äôre familiar with his history, standing in this magnificent mausoleum is a humbling experience.  The Mus√©e de l‚ÄôArm√©e (Army Museum) is another highlight of the H√¥tel des Invalides. It boasts one of the most comprehensive collections of military artifacts in the world. The exhibits cover everything from medieval armor to World War II weaponry. The sections dedicated to the Napoleonic Wars are particularly engaging, featuring detailed displays of uniforms, weapons, and strategies that bring this pivotal era to life. The museum‚Äôs layout is informative and accessible, making it enjoyable for both history buffs and casual visitors.  In addition to the museum and Napoleon‚Äôs tomb, the Saint-Louis-des-Invalides Church is worth exploring. This serene and beautiful church, still serving veterans today, seamlessly blends with the larger complex. The church‚Äôs stunning stained glass and elegant design offer a peaceful retreat amid the historical grandeur.  The Charles de Gaulle Memorial adds a modern historical touch, with exhibits that explore his contributions to shaping 20th-century France. This thoughtful addition helps connect the site‚Äôs past with more recent history.  The H√¥tel des Invalides is located in the 7th arrondissement, a short walk from the Eiffel Tower and the Seine River, making it an easy addition to your itinerary. I recommend dedicating 2-3 hours to fully experience everything. The staff are friendly, and guided tours are available for those wanting deeper insights. There is also a bookshop and caf√© on-site for souvenirs or refreshments.  In summary, the H√¥tel des Invalides offers a rich and immersive experience of French history, military heritage, and stunning architecture. Whether you‚Äôre captivated by Napoleon, fascinated by military history, or simply want to admire one of Paris‚Äôs most beautiful landmarks, this destination is well worth a visit.
Wonderful museum and monument to France's military history. Easy enough to enter without any advance tickets.

Yesterday, I visited the H√¥tel des Invalides in Paris, and it was an incredible experience. This historic complex, originally built in the 17th century as a home for injured soldiers, now houses museums and monuments dedicated to France‚Äôs military history. The most impressive sight is the Dome Church, where Napoleon Bonaparte's tomb lies, surrounded by stunning architecture and intricate gold details.  I was surprised to learn that entry to the complex is free, which is amazing considering how much history you can explore within. The Mus√©e de l'Arm√©e, one of the largest military museums in the world, is located inside and offers fascinating exhibits ranging from medieval armor to World War II memorabilia. If you're a history buff, this place is a must-visit.  The grounds themselves are also beautiful, with manicured lawns and statues of famous French military leaders. Even if you're not into military history, the architecture and peaceful atmosphere make it worth the trip. Be sure to give yourself plenty of time to explore, as there's so much to see. Overall, I highly recommend a visit to the H√¥tel des Invalides ‚Äì it's a perfect blend of history, beauty, and culture.
Fascinating place to visit for a perspective on the rich topic of French military history. Culminating with a view of Napoleon's mausoleum.
Wow so impressed. I can‚Äôt believe I hadn‚Äôt been there all this time. Napoleon‚Äôs tomb is just breathtaking
Was a wonder to see! The sheer majesty of Napoleon's tomb is quite something, and anyone visiting Paris should definitely visit whilst here.
Beautiful place. There are both tomb of napoleon and army museum inside. Both worth visiting. I suggest Paris Museum Pass but there were not much people waiting either.

I was truly impressed by the scale and beauty of Les Invalides in Paris. This is an impressive building that is definitely worth a visit. Inside, you can find several museums dedicated to the military history of France. You can see many exhibits, including weapons, uniforms, and other items related to wars. Also, in Les Invalides, there is the tomb of Napoleon Bonaparte. This is a place of pilgrimage for many tourists. I recommend visiting Les Invalides if you are interested in the history of France and military equipment. You will not be disappointed!

It‚Äôs a same complex where the church and museum are. It used to be (during Louis XV and XI) a hospital for the war veterans as well as the retirement home for military personnel. It‚Äôs where the Napoleon found his resting place (in the church near the home/museum).  Visiting Paris means visiting Hotel des Invalides. It‚Äôs a must visit place.  Enjoy!

A lot of expositions about the role of France in World War I and World War II. If you have seversl hours of free time in Paris, then definitely visit the museum in H√¥tel des Invalides. Also, don't forget to take a look at Napoleon's tomb, which is under the golden dome.

I've visited the H√¥tel des Invalides a few times now, and each time it takes my breath away. The complex is steeped in history and magnificence, making it a place that always captivates me. There are two main entrances to explore: I recommend entering through the museum entrance, as it‚Äôs the most grand, taking you through the impressive courtyard first. However, the entrance near Napoleon's tomb is also great for those who want to capture a stunning photo from the outside.  You don't need to buy tickets ahead of time, but it's much more convenient, especially if you have a museum pass. The museum and Napoleon's tomb have separate entrances, so it doesn't matter which one you visit first. If you plan to explore the museum, be prepared for a thorough visit, as there's a lot to see. But if you're short on time, visiting Napoleon's tomb is perfect for a quick in-and-out experience. Make sure to go downstairs to get a closer view of the tomb and take some time to sit on the benches and admire the breathtaking murals on the ceiling.  Within the complex, there‚Äôs also a cafeteria where you can grab some drinks and food if you need a break. And don't forget to check out the gift shop for some wonderful souvenirs to remember your visit.
Really interesting and complete museum. Save a good amount of time to spend here, stayed for 2h30 and had to rush through the last sections which I really regret.

At the H√¥tel des Invalides, tourists can enjoy a remarkable free experience by visiting La Cour de l'Honneur, the main courtyard facing the Seine[5]. This impressive space showcases centuries-old canons and stunning architecture without any admission fee. Additionally, visitors can enter the Cath√©drale Saint-Louis-des-Invalides at no cost, where they might be lucky enough to catch an impromptu organ concert[5]. These areas offer a glimpse into the historical and architectural grandeur of the complex, allowing tourists to appreciate its significance without spending a euro. The H√¥tel des Invalides is an exceptional complex in Paris, both in size and historical significance. Its fa√ßade facing the Seine is an impressive 196 meters (643 feet) wide, making it one of the largest military structures in Europe[2]. The complex features fifteen courtyards, with the largest being the Cour d'Honneur, designed for military parades[7].  One of the most remarkable aspects of Les Invalides is its iconic golden dome, which stands 107 meters (351 feet) tall, making it the tallest church building in Paris[7][10]. This dome is decorated with 12.65 kilograms (27.9 pounds) of gold leaf, creating a stunning landmark visible from afar[10].  Historically, Les Invalides played a crucial role during the French Revolution. On July 14, 1789, Parisian rioters stormed the complex and seized cannons and muskets from its cellars, which were then used in the attack on the Bastille later that same day[7]. This event marked a significant moment in the beginning of the French Revolution.

A stunning museum! Mostly famous for being the location of Napoleon‚Äôs tomb however the museum has so much more to offer! It is a very large museum which covers almost the entire history of France. We‚Äôve enjoyed this museum greatly and I can confidently say that we‚Äôve seen a small fraction of it although we‚Äôve spent almost 3 hours. The downside is that toilets are very poorly marked, the staff speaks very poor English to give directions and the large complex can give the impression that you are in a maze.

Worth a visiting. Interesting, huge. The only note is that the Napoleons tomb is basically a marketing scam. As they mention an entry fee and tickets, but you don't need them for the tomb, only the Army museum.

This was a great day out with so much to see. It's worth buying a ticket to see as much as possible. When I visited there was an immersive exhibition about the liberation of France. It was very moving as it included people's stories, so not just about military tactics. It was a Sunday in November, very quiet and no queuing for tickets. The cafe is worth a visit too.

Visited in the evening for the AURA experience and it was amazing! The line to get in was huge but once you were inside it didn‚Äôt feel as busy. I just wish it provided more actual information on the story besides a few sentences.
Fabulous, mostly free, only pay if you want to see Napoleons resting place

This was our first stop on the Batobus route we took. Our original plan was to pass through the Invalides and click some pictures from outside but the grand golden dome attracted us and we couldn't stop ourselves from visiting the courtyard and enjoyed the grandness and architecture.  The grand golden dome houses tomb of Nepolian.
Wow ü§© what an amazing museum with sooo much to see. Really good organized and friendly staff around.

Worth visiting! Helps you understand what Napoleon was about. Off the high season (beginning of June) on a weekday we didn‚Äôt need to get tickets in advance, just walked in. Can be combined perfectly with the Rodin Museum.

It is a great museum with tons of interesting stuff.  The challenge for most will be that the museum goes into incredible detail and the visitor has to be prepared to move quickly through some portions and decide for themselves what is most important to them to learn, otherwise you will either be there six or more hours or you will run out of energy and time.
If you are curious about war history and France, you must definitely see this place. Very enthusiastic
Beautiful and interesting place, full of history and the museum has amazing artifacts!!!

The heart of French army lies in Invalides. But the main section is the tomb of Napoleon, the hero of France. It is located exactly under the golden dome of Invalides. Visit it first and then if you have time, you can explore other sections such as the army museum, Charles de Gaulle section, maps section and other stuff. Overall you need at least 3 hours to see everything but it shortage of time then Tomb of Napoleon is a must visit section. All sections of Invalides are included in Paris Museum Pass.

This was one of the best experiences of our trip to Paris being an Indian. It was lovely food and ambience. It is a fine restaurant and I highly recommend every Indian to go there whenever they visit Paris, specially for special occasions, such as honeymoon. It is the fusion of Indian food with French essence on some of the dishes. However, the restaurant owner recommends you the best dishes and the taste that you would like it is a must must must visit place.

I got the tickets before hand but being an EU citizen under 26 meant I got in for free. I spent around 7 hours inside, looking at every single thing they had exposed and they have so much. They have a bit of Roman artifacts and Chinese and Japanese stuff that came as gifts from ambassadors of the past, but it mainly focuses on an incredibly big collection from the 1200s onwards. They have a lot of medieval armor and weaponry and the entire tour really shows the evolution of both the armor, the weapons and the roles and tactics of war, taking you to a trip through time from knights in shining armor to occupied France. I highly recommend to check this place out if you like history, there's so much to look and read you are bound to find something interesting.
Definitely a cool site to check out if you are in Paris! We had an amazing time here.
Great place to visit. Lots of information and history, covering the military history of France as well as an old hospital and Old Soldiers' retirement home.
